lesson_html:
Logical operators in Python are similar to those in C#, used to perform boolean logic operations. The three main logical operators are:

  • and: Equivalent to C#'s && operator. Returns True if both operands are true.
  • or: Equivalent to C#'s || operator. Returns True if at least one operand is true.
  • not: Equivalent to C#'s ! operator. Negates the boolean value.

Example of logical operators:

x = True
y = False

# AND operator
print(x and y)  # False

# OR operator
print(x or y)   # True

# NOT operator
print(not x)    # False

In Python, logical operators can also work with non-boolean values, returning the first 'falsy' or last 'truthy' value.

    - has_license (bool): Whether person has a valid driver's license
    - is_insured (bool): Whether person has car insurance

test_py:
from solution import check_eligibility

def test_check_eligibility():
    assert check_eligibility(20, True, True) == True
    assert check_eligibility(17, True, True) == False
    assert check_eligibility(25, False, True) == False
